Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.573 - Northern Andes Seasonal Dry Forest NE'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.573 - Northern Andes Seasonal Dry Forest NE'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.El.573 - Northern Andes Seasonal Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.El Tropical Andean Montane Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Dosel irregular, sotobosque menos denso, menos epifitas y estratos mas baja. Composicion floristica como Fabaceaes, Bombaceaes, Meliaceae, Bignonaceae y Burseraceae.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Sub-humedo del norte de los Andes Se encuentra en las faldas de los Andes de Venezuela, Colombia y Ecuador en valles interandinos o en la transicion a lugares estacionales secos
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Cordillera La Costa montane forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.1.El.573 - Northern Andes Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: This assessment unit was not evaluated due to inconsistency in its distribution data.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was not evaluated for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was not evaluated for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was not evaluated for this assessment unit.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.574 - Central Andes Seasonal Dry Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.574 - Central Andes Seasonal Dry Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.El.574 - Central Andes Seasonal Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.El Tropical Andean Montane Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Efecto medio a moderado de lluvia de sombra orografica

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los Bsq. SC son densos, altos y con varios niveles d sotobosque con varias lianas leñosas

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Semi-caducifoleos (SC), 2. Bsq. Sub-humedos Se distribuye en piso montanos inferior de las laderas orientales de los Andes de Perú hasta el centro-sur de Bolivia. Al norte en la parte oriental de Huancabanba (Valle del Marañón al sur de Ecuador y norte de Perú). Al sur en los valles interandinos de los Yungas al centro de Perú o en Cochabamba en Bolivia.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.1.El.574 - Central Andes Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- NT.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Argentina

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Argentina
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.1.El.574 - Central Andes Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup in Argentina.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, and is considered Least Concern.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of recent changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of predicted future changes in tree cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of historical changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A2b

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of predicted future changes in tree cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest NT (NT -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest NT (NT -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.El Tropical Andean Montane Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Estrucuta de Bsq. denso, alto (20-25 m), presencia de lianas leñosas y varios estratos de subdosel.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Semi-caducifolios Se encuentra en el centro-sur de Bolivia (Santa Cruz, Chuquisaca, Tarija), al sur hasta Salta (region florisitica Boliviano-Tucumano); al noroeste de Argentina. Ente los 800 y 1900 msnm.

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criteria and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os NT -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of VU -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Argentina
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup in Argentina.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, and is considered Least Concern.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b

Subcriterion.name: A3

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Bolivia
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.1.El.575 - Boliviano Tucumano Seasonal Dry Forest' macrogroup in Bolivia.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3

Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.
